Congratulations on investing in your own sculpting tools! Working with earthenware clay can be a wonderful medium, and with practice and patience, you can achieve amazing results. I'd be happy to help you improve your sculpting techniques and get the texture just right. Here are some tips to get you started:

1. **Understand your clay**: Earthenware clay can be quite forgiving, but it's essential to understand its properties. It's a relatively soft clay, which means it can be prone to cracking and drying out quickly. Keep your clay covered when not in use, and make sure it's at the right consistency for sculpting.
2. **Prepare your clay**: Before starting to sculpt, make sure your clay is wedged and conditioned. Wedging removes any air pockets and makes the clay more pliable, while conditioning helps to achieve a consistent texture. You can do this by kneading the clay like dough, folding and refolding it several times.
3. **Start with a solid foundation**: Create a sturdy base or armature to support your sculpture. This will help prevent it from collapsing or warping as you work. You can use a wire armature or a solid clay base, depending on the size and complexity of your piece.
4. **Use the right tool for the job**: You've already invested in a set of loop tools, which are excellent for shaping and smoothing out the clay. Use the wire cutter to refine details and create textures. Experiment with different tools to achieve the desired effect.
5. **Work in small sections**: Divide your sculpture into smaller areas and focus on one section at a time. This will help you maintain control and avoid over-working the clay, which can lead to cracks and uneven textures.
6. **Build up gradually**: Instead of trying to achieve a specific texture all at once, build up layers of clay gradually. This will help you achieve a more organic, natural look. Use your loop tools to smooth out each layer before adding the next.
7. **Use gentle, sweeping motions**: When using your loop tools, use gentle, sweeping motions to shape and smooth the clay. Apply gentle pressure, especially when working on delicate areas.
8. **Add texture with intention**: When adding texture, use a deliberate, controlled motion. Experiment with different techniques, such as pressing, scoring, or stamping, to achieve the desired effect.
9. **Don't over-work the clay**: Earthenware clay can become brittle and prone to cracking if over-worked. Stop working on a section when it's almost perfect, and let it rest for a few minutes before returning to it.
10. **Practice, practice, practice**: The more you work with earthenware clay, the more comfortable you'll become with its properties and the techniques required to achieve the desired texture. Don't be discouraged if your early attempts don't turn out as expected – keep practicing, and you'll see improvement over time.
11. **Study the work of others**: Look at the work of other ceramic artists, both online and in person. Analyze the textures and techniques they've used, and try to incorporate those elements into your own work.
12. **Experiment and take risks**: Don't be afraid to try new techniques or take risks with your sculpture. This is where some of the most interesting and unique textures can emerge.

By following these tips, you'll be well on your way to achieving the textures you want with earthenware clay. Remember to stay patient, persistent, and open to experimentation, and you'll see improvement in your sculpting techniques over time. Good luck, and have fun!
